With ugly blacks of lust; what would you do?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O tis too hard a question to resolve,
Without a solemne Councell held within
Of mans best understanding faculties:
There must be love, and fatherhood, and griefe,
And rage, and many passions, and they must all
Beget a thing call'd vengeance; but they must sit upon't.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Say this were done by him that carried
The fairest seeming face of friendship to your selfe.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: We should fall out.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Would you in such a case respect degrees?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I know not that.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Say he were noble.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Impossible: th'acts ignoble, the Bee can breed
No poyson, though it sucke the iuyce of hemlocke.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Say a king should doo 't? 'Twereth' art lesse done
By the greater power, does Maiesty extenuate a crime:

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Augment it rather.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Say then that Rodericke, your king and Master,
To quit the honours you are bringing home,
Had ravisht your Iacinta.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Who has sent
A furie in this fowle-faire shape to vexe me?
I ha seene that face me thinks, yet know it not:
How darest thou speake this treason, gainst my king?
Durst any man ith world, bring me this lye,
By this, had been in hell; Rodoricke a Tarquin?

sp.speaker: Iacin.
sp.l: Yes, and thy daughter (had she done her part)
Should be the second Lucrece: view me well,
I am Iacinta.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: The king my ravisher.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: The king thy ravisher! oh unkingly sound:
He dares not sure, yet in thy sullied eyes
I reade a Tragicke story.
O noble friends,
Our warres are ended, are they not?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: They are Sir.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: But Spaine has now begun a civill warre.
And to confound me onely: see you my daughter?
She sounds the Trumpet, which draws forth my sword
To be revengde.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: On whom? speake loud your wrongs,
Digest your choller into temperance:
Give your considerate thoughts the upper hand,
In your hot passions, twill asswage the swelling
Of your big heart; if you have iniuries done you,
Revenge them, and we second you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Father, deare father.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Daughter, deare daughter.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Why do you kneele to me Sir?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: To aske thee pardon that I did beget thee,
I brought thee to a shame staines all the way
Twixt earth and Acheron: not all the clouds
(The skies large canopy) could they drowne the Seas
With a perpetuall inundation,
Can wash it ever out, leave me I pray.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: His fighting passions will be ore anon,
And all will be at peace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Best in my iudgement,
We wake him with the fight of his won honours:
Call up the army, and let them present
His prisoners to him, such a sight as that
Will brooke no sorrow neare it.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Twas a good Doctor that prescrib'de that physick
I'le be your patient Sir, shew me my souldiers,
And my new honours won, I will truly weigh them,
With my full griefes, they may perhaps orecome.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Why now theres hope of his recovery.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Iacinta welcome, thou art my child still,
No forced staine of lust can alienate
Our consanguinitie.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Deare Father,
Recollect your noble spirits, conquer griefe,
The manly way: you have brave foes subdued,
Then let no female passions thus orewhelme you.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Mistake me not, my childe, I am not mad,
Nor must be idle; for it were more fit,
(If I could purchase more) I had more wit,
To helpe in these designes, I am growne old:
Yet I have found more strength within this arme,
Then without proofe I durst ha boasted on.
Rodericke thou king of monsters couldst thou do this?
And for thy lust confine me from the Court,
There's reason in thy shame, thou shouldst not see me.
Ha! they come Iacinta, they come, hearke, hearke,
Now thou shalt see what cause I have given my king:
sp.stage: Enter Antonio with the Affrican king, and other Moores prisoners.
sp.l: Stand, pray stand all, deliver me my prisoners:
So t well, wondrous well, I have no friends
But these my enemies, yet welcome brave Moores,
With you Ile parley; first I defle you all.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I am a vowd for to your King, to Roderique.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How Iulianus!

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nay we feare you not, here's our whole army;
Yet we are strong enough from feare or flight.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Make us understand a reason Iulianus,
If for disloyalty reason may be given
Of this your language.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Be you my Iudges whom I make my foes?
Was my power plac't above my mercy, or mercy
Above my power? went they not hand in hand?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ever most nobly.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Ever, ever.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Why then should Roderique doe this base deed?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You doe distract us Sir, beseech you name it.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Behold this child of mine, this onely mine,
I had a daughter, be she is ravisht now.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ravisht?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yes, by Roderique, by lustfull, tyrant, Roderique:

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: O most abhorrid deed?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ioyne with me noble Spaniards in Revenge.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: We will.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Have I your hearts?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Our lives shall seale it.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Then Princely Mulymumen, here I free thee,
And all thy valiant Moores: Wilt thou call back
Thy scattered forces, and incorporate
Their strengths with mine, and with me march through Spaine,
Sharpning thy sword with vengeance for my wrongs?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Most willingly, to binde me father to thee,
Plight me thy ravisht daughter to my wife,
And thou shalt see my indignation fly
On wings of Thunder.

sp.speaker: Iacin:
sp.l: O my second hell,
A Christians armes embrace an infidell!

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ile not compell her heart, wooe, win, and wed her:
Forc't has she bin too much,— My honor'd friends,
What We all thought to ha borne home in Triumph,
Must now be seene there in a Funerall,
Wrackt Honour being chiefe Mourner; here's the Herse
Which weele all follow;— Roderique we come,
To give thy lust a scourge, thy life a doome.

div.stage: A bed discovered, on it Lazarello, as Antonio: Enter Margaretta and Fydella with a halter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sleepes he Fydella?

sp.speaker: Fyd.
sp.l: Slumbringly Madam; hee's not yet in his dead sleepe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tis now his dying, anon comes his dead sleep.
For never shall he wake, untill the world
Hath Phoenix-like bin hid in his owne ashes,
Fydella, take my strength into thine armes,
And play the cruell executioner,
As I will first instruct thee.

sp.speaker: Fyd.
sp.l: I am so farre
From shrinking, Madam, that Ile gladly be
The Prologue to Antonios Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Antonios Tragedy! that very Name
Should strike even sparkes of pitty from the flint:
Antonio! husband Antonio.

sp.speaker: Fyd.
sp.l: Remember there's another owes that Name.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I, that's that's the poyson kils me; shall a strumpet
(For shee's no better) rob me of a treasure
So deere to me as he was; yet her I pardon:
The master-thiefe lies here, and he must dye fort:
All mercy hence I banish. Iustice looke downe
To see a womans vengeance; thus I begin,
And follow thus and thus, now I am in,
Nothing shall pull me back.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Fyd.
sp.l: He has passage yet for breath.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Here's remedy for that, pull Fydella.

sp.speaker: Fyd.
sp.l: He woud speake it seemes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Never; his tongue betrayd me once, I will
No more listen my temptations; heare he shall
A while, and that but deafly: Antonio,
I was your wife, Lordly Antonio,
And in that balance equal'd with your selfe,
I was your handmaid, and you might have trod
On my humility, I had kist your feet,
But with disdaine thou trampledst on my throat,
As I doe now on thine, and will deface
What nature built for honor, not deceit:
Our wedding was in private, so our divorce,
Yet this shall have as fre and open blazon
As a truth-speaking goodnesse; O my Fydella,
Thou little instrument of my revenge,
I woud not have thee (for thy duty) lost,
There's gold; hye thee to safety, fare thee well,
I must nere see thee more, this place will be—

sp.speaker: Fyd.
sp.l: Not too hot for me Madam; my complexion
Is naturall to it: good fortunes follow you;
If I might counsell you, I woud conceale it:
If you can fly, doe not betray your selfe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fy, prethee away, thou wilt marre all the glory,
Conceale the deed? even to the bended brow
Of the sterne Iudge, Ile speake, and call for iustice,
Proud of my glorious vengeance, I will smile
Vpon my dreadfull Executioner:
Twas that was first enacted in my brest,
She shoud not dare to kill, that dares not die,
Tis needy mischiefe, and hee's basely bent
That dares doe ill, yet feare the punishment.

div.head: Actus quintus.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: SOme musique.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Musique Sir! tis all untunde,
Remember your proud enemies approach,
And your unreadinesse to entertaine um.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: If all be set upon a carelesse hazard,
What shall care doe there?

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Rouze you like a Lion,
And fright this heard of Foxes, Wolves, and Beares,
From daring to come neere you: a Kings eye.
Has Magicall charmes in't to binde treason down,
They fight like theeves for spoile, you for your owne;

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O Piamentelli, theres within my bosome,
An army of Furies mustred, worse than those
Which follow Iulianus: Conscience beats
The Drum of horror up.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: For what! a Meidenhead!
Pray be your selfe, and justifie the act,
Stand on your guard, and royalize the fact
By your owne dispensation.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Goe call our friends together, if we have none,
Hire them with double pay, our selfe will search
And breake those dangerous doores which have so long
Kept Spaine in childish ignorance.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: O good my Lord,
Forbeare, there's fatall prophesies forbid you.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: There's fatall fooleries; tell me of prophesies!
Shall feare affright me? no; upon my life
Tis hidden treasure kept for needfull houres,
And now tis come; tis gold must purchase soldiers;
Shall I not seeke it then? alone Ile breake
Ope those forbidden doores, goe muster men.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: This I dread more then all our enemies,
If good proceed from this, no Magick Art
Shall fright me.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Or good, or bad, Ile throw the dice my selfe,
And take the chance that fals; thou art the first,
Hell wakens, yet Ile on, twenty at least
I must passe through before I breake the spell,
If this doore thither lead, Ile enter hell.

div.stage: Thunder and Lightning. Enter Roderique againe at another doore.

sp.speaker: Rod
sp.l: So now I me entred to the fatall chamber,
Shew now thy full effects, ha? what sight's this?

div.stage: Enter Iulianus, Moore, Iaciuta, Antonio, Alonzo, one presenting Roderique.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Tis holliday in hell, the fiends are loose,
I have enfranchiz'd you, thank me Devils;
Was this the fatall incantation
That here was lockt so many fearfull ages,
And was't decreed for me to dislocate?
Fire consume you geomantick Devils,
Where borrowed you those bodies, you damn'd theeves?
In your owne shapes you are not visible,
Or are you yet but fancies imaginarie?
What's he that me presents? I have not sent
My carcas forth, I am not sleeping now,
And my soule straid forth, I am my reall selfe,
Must I be captiv'd by a traitor so?
Devill thou playest me false; undiadem'd?
And such a sooty fiend inherit me?
Iacinta, too, that she-curse, must she have part?
Kneeling to them, here's a solemnity
In the Devils name; goe raigne in Sulphur, or in
Some frozen Labyrinth; this Kingdom's mine:
Thou there that me personat'st, draw forth thy sword,
And brandish't against hell, Ile shew thee how?
What Magick bindes me? what furies hold mine arme.
Piamentelli, Avilla, none succour me?

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: What ayles you Sir?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: My foes are come upon me.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Comming they are, but yet a league distant, Sir,

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Zounds they are come, and have bin here with me.
Traiterous Iulianus, and his ravisht daughter,
An army of Moores, of Turks and infidels.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Your fancies trouble you, they are but comming,
Too neere in that, make up to your souldiers,
Full twenty thousand now will follow you and more.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: The Moore's a comming, & the devill too that must
Succeed me in my last monarchy, take armes and fight,
The fiends shall know they have not plaid me right.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p:
O for a private place to bee hang'd in; when all hope's gone, welcome despaire; which way soever the day goes, I'me sure this is my way; If the King overcome, I shall be hang'd for Iacintaes escape, if shee rise, I fall in recompence of her wrongs. All my griefe is, I want an heire to have my purse and clothes, one that would take the paines for me, an honest hangman were now as good
a companion as I woud desire to meet with; I have liv'd a Lord, and I woud be loath to dye an executioner.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Murder is come to light; Oh sister how hast thou overthrowne our honorable house before it was well covered; oh ambitious sister, halfe a share in a Lord woud not content thee, thou woud have all or none, now thou hast none, for thou hast kild thy Lord and husband.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I was a Lord, altho a bawdy Lord.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I was a Lords brother, altho a bawdy Lords brother.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: O Lechery, how hast thou puft mee up and undone me.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O Lechery, thou hast battend me a while, and then spoild me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Ha? what art thou?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Partly honorable, partly miserable.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Give me thy halter then.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Art thou a hangman then?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I, and a mad one, but now I droope, and am ready to drop into the budget.

sp.speaker: Lo,
sp.p: Looke here's worke for thee, here's clothes, and here's mony, wout thou take the paines to hang me?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I have liv'd a Lords brother, and woud be loath to die a hangman.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Doe not desire to die, live till thou diest of thine owne accord.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Tis my desire, but I want a cord of mine owne, prethee lend me thine.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Let me perswade thee to be charitable to thy selfe, spare thy selfe, and hang me, I have beene a Pander, knowst thou what a Pander is?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: In briefe a knave; more at large thus;
Hee's a thing that is poore,
He waits upon a whore,
When shee's sick, hee's sore,
In the streets he goes before,
At the chamber waits at doore,
All his life a runs o'th score,
This I know, and know no more.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: All this Ile adde to it,
He weares long locke,
And villanous socks,
Many nights in the stocks,
Endures some knocks,
And a many of mocks,
Eates reversions of cocks,
Yet lies in the flocks,
Thrives by the smocks,
And dies with the pox.
All this I have beene, and now desire to be hang'd for't.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: What hast thou there?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: A hundred marks, besides leases, and lands which I have wickedly gotten, all which I will bestow on thee, if thou wilt take the paines to hang me.

sp.speaker: Iaq:
sp.p: Hum? my brother is dead, and there is no way to raise our house agen but by ready money or credit; the hangman many times mounts above his betters; well I will hang, but my conscience beares me witnesse, tis not for any good will I beare unto thee, nor for any wrong that I know thou hast committed; but innocently for thy lands, thy leases, thy clothes, and thy money. And so come along with to me the next tree, where thou shalt hang till thou art dead, and stink above ground.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: With all my heart, my guts, my lights, my liver, and my lungs.

div.stage: Alarum, Excursions, Enter Rodorique and Piamentelli.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Fly, fly my Lord.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: With what wings?

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: With wings of speed.
Your foes, Sir, conquer, and your souldies bleed,
The barbarous Moore is titled by your name,
The Spanish King; therefore your safest speed
Will be to Biscany, there you may finde
New friends, new safety, and new kingly mindes.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: There is no friendship where there is no power,
I must crave now, oh poverty most poore,
To beg of them receiv'd mine almes, before.
I have defended them:

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: They'le you releeve.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Ile make the proofe: what do you call the man
Whose prowesse in that rightfull victory
Against the Moores did so much honor win?

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Antonio.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: He was, and is, and may be, but not long?
This poyson'd Iulianus has batterd him.
Thou art my subject still Piamentelli.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.l: Whilst I am Piamentelli.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Wert thou gone,
I then might boast, I were a King alone,
For but thy selfe I doe not know one subject,
Then subjects all, since you le not let me die,
Ile seeke a weary life in Biscany.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Thou mutable peece of nature, dost thou fly me?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Th'at's frightfull to me.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: I shall be more frightfull,
If thou repell a proferd arme of love,
There will rebound a hate blacker in Art
Then in similitude; forget me not,
Have not I chac't thy wronger from his ground,
And my triumphant selfe thy conqueror?
I am thy King.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Ile feare thee then?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Not love me!

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: The word is poison'd in thy very tongue,
Love thee? as I would love my ravisher.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Thy father shall repent.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: He must, and will,
That ere he freed a captive infidell.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Looke for a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Yes, some barbarous one,
Tis naturall to thee, base African,
Thine in side a blacker then thy sooty skin.
Oh Iulianus, what hast thou done? thast scap't
The raging Lion, to wrastle with a Dragon,
He would have slaine with a majesticke gripe.
But this with venome; better had bin thy fate
By him to fall, then thus, by such a helhound.

div.stage: Enter Moore and Soldiers, with Iulianus.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Bring forth that traytor, same that lustfull whore.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What wilt thou monster?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Any thing that's monstrous.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Reward a traytor.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Traytor?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Be thine owne iudge,
What art thou but thy Kings, and Kingdomes ruine?
Was it thy hopes, that ever I should trust thee?
Traytors are poyson'd arrowes drawne toth' head.
Which we shoot home at mischiefe; being struck dead,
Then let the arrow be consumed in fire.
Hast not betrayd thy King and Country basely

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: For thee (ingratefull, villanous Moore) I have,
I have deserv'd to die, but not by thee,
And I beseech thee, bloody Tyrant, hasten
My punishment.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: That boone is easily granted.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Tis now full glory to thee, to strike home
Set the black character of death upon me,
Give me a sentence horrid as thy selfe art,
Speake in thy barbarous language, thy last doome,
A tyrants Axe sends me to a blest home.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Pluck out his eyes, and her exclaiming tongue,
She shall in silent sorrow then lead him,
Her eyes shall be his starres.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O spare her tyrant.
By her offence and wrong thou hast aspirde,
Then tread not on her vertues, 'tis enough
That I doe suffer for the good ill I did
To set thy captiv'd foot above my head:
Oh spare my child.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Entreat for me? forbeare Sir,
Either be you dumbe or let him not heare,
I shall have mentall prayers left for heaven,
Fuller effectuall then this tongue can utter.
And for the author of my wrongs and sinne,
I shall have harty curses left.

div.stage: Enter Margaretta the body of Lazarello Pedro, and Claveile.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Iustice, Iustice, thou that filst the throne
Of soveraigne Iustice, thou art a severe one.
Give me thy sharpest rigor.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Against whom?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My selfe the murdresse of my valiant husband.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: More fruits of Christians.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, and see, here's more,
Antonios ghost! murdred by me, yet liv'st thou?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Revenge and jealousie misled thy arme.
To kill my friend, (my supposde friend) not me.
Thou strangledst Lazarello.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O my hard fate!
My aim, was full at thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: End thy just hate,
For I am parting from thee; see those two
That wrong'd thee are both wounded to the death,
With griefe she, I by poyson lose my breath.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Forgive him, but spare not me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How came you wounded?
I clap my hands at this your tragedy,
My birth was base, but my revenge flew high.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: A noble girle, a lusty stout Virago.

sp.speaker: Aut.
sp.l: Iulianus, for a wrong done to his daughter,
(The fatall Engine that hath beat downe Spaine)
Revolted from his King, and set that Moore up,
Who now insults, being but a captive then,
And cause in honest language I was just
In taxing this revolt of Iulianus,
He bid a soldier kill me, who refusing it,
He himselfe struck me; life was lent thus long,
But for the clensing of my conscience:
I feele deathe pangs, forgive me both, and all,
Let my soule rise, altho my body full
With honor I got honor, thus my sinne thrives,
Thus fals the wretched husband of two wives

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: So, here's a brace of widowes now at one windfall,
A wholsome example to all succession;
Let every wise man take heed of two wives,
Tis too great ods, I durst be one of the two
My selfe should break one of the strongest husbands hearts.
What should I call thee, widow, shall wee marry one another now.
And beget Chimeraes, I doe not thinke
That ever any at once husband dares venture
On us both at once again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Dost thou play with thunder, or is that thing
Which should supply the place of soule in thee,
Merely phantasticall? are thy passions
Such featherd follies, idle gigglotories?
Are these the rites due to a funerall?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Why? hast never seene the sun-shine of a rainy day?
Who does beleeve a widows teares to be her hearts sorrow?
Are they not then better spa'rd then derided?
Let me see then what thou dar'st do with wet eyes,
That I dare not answere with a smiling cheeke?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What thou dar'st not second I dare doe.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Begin, Ile pledge thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou dar'st not.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Try me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thus then I come to thee Antonio;
Thou didst forsake me living, being dead
I will enjoy thy monumentall bed.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I, hast thou that resolution?
Me thinkes a woman (as I am) should not out do me,
I must dye one day, and as good this day as another,
Whereabouts is my heart, I thinke all over my body,
I am all heart, and therefore cannot misse,
Some creatures dye singing, why not I merrily,
Make me roome Antonio and Margaretta,
Weele all tumble in one bed together,
Ile lie as close as shee on thy left side,
And have as many kisses too, that's my bargaine;
My sinnes are all upon thy conscience,
But I forgive thee, and heaven be the Clarke to't,
My soule will have free passage, my body I bequeath
To thee Antonio, I am your wife,
And will come to bed to you, thus I make unready,
Thus I lie downe, thus kisse, and this embrace
Ile ever keepe, I am weary now with play,
I needs must sleepe for ever.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Excellent pastime

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Tis night with me for ever, where's this tyrant?
Turne me but to him, and from these darkned eyes
I shall discover his Cymerian face,
For tho all is darke, yet still that's visible,
And nothing else to me; see ran here villaine,
Looke what a bloody pageant thou hast made;
I borrow eyes to guide me of my child,
And her Ile lend a tongue to curse thee with.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Thou laughest at misery.
Tis well, thou giuest a grave unto my sorrowes,
Yet wherefore shouldst thou glory in't? this worke
Is none of thine, tis heavens mercifull iustice,
For thou art but the executioner,
The master hangman, and those ministers
That did these bloody ravishments upon's,
Thy second slaves, and yet I more deserve,
I was a traytor to my lawfull King,
And tho my wrongs encited on my rage,
I had no warrant signed for my revenge,
Tis the peoples sinnes that makes tyrants Kings,
And such was mine for thee, now I obey,
But my affliction teaches me too late,
On bloody revenger, finish up my fate.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: The rest shall noble be, He not confine
Nor give thee living in captivity,
Thy body shall enjoy the generall prison.
But thy soule set free.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Thou art good in that, and noble.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Nay it shall nobler be in the performance,
Give him weapons, thou art a soldier,
And shalt end so; Ile be thy opposite,
With ods of eyes, but not of armes, I vow,
If thy darke ayme hit in my face, Ile stand,
And die with thee, if not, fall by my hand.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Thoul't hurt my penitence, for I shall blesse
All the ill deeds that I have done for thee,
In this so noble end,

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: By pr prepar'd then.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: One thing more of thee, be a prophet to me first,
For thou know'st what shall become of my poore Iacinta,
What end to her is fated.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Before thy end thou shalt know it.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Oh let it noble be, and honourable;
Her life has had too many strokes of sorrowes;
Oh let her end be sparing.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: It shall be noble too.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I beg for her that has no tongue to beg,
And what remaines my saint yeelding breath,
Shall all be spent in blessings over thee:
Farewell Iacinta, take my latest blessing,
I know thy soule returnes a thanks to me,
Make haste to overtake me, if thou beest stayd,
Thinke of Cleopatra and Brutus wife,
There's many wayes to end a weary life.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Come Sir, I stand before you.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Thur I come,
Thy death Ile venter, but receive mine owne,
So, I have my doome, and I have hit too.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Laughest thou? I am am deluded then.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: O bloody homicide, thou hast slaine thy daughter.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: False villaine, hast thou then so mockt my woes,
To make me fatall butcher of my child?
Was she the target to defend thy body?
Forgive me my Iacinta, 'twas in me
An innocent act of blood, but tyranny
In that black monster: 'tis not much ill,
Better my hand then a worse arme should spill
Thy guiltlesse life; what art thou going yet?
Thy warme blood cooles, my sunne begins to set,
Nature shrinkes backward to her former formes,
Our soules climbe stars, whilst these descend to wormes.
See tyrant, from thy further strokes we fly,
Heaven do thy will, I will not cursing die.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: So, now we live beholding unto none
Vpon this stayre we do ascend our throne,
Give us our title.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Long live Mullimumen King of Spaine.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Your silence it confirmes, take hence their bodies,
Give them to Christians, and let them bestow
What ceremonious funerals they please.
We must pursue the flying Rodorique.
All must be ours, weele have no Kingdome sharer,
Let Chroniclers write, here we begin our raigne,
The first of Moores that ere was King of Spaine.
